When my son was in high school, he volunteered one summer in an organization in Bogotá that was developing a curriculum for peace education in schools located in poor and conflict-affected regions of the country. It was not glamorous work and he did it at a time when few thought that a negotiated settlement to the armed conflict was possible.

The experience likely had little impact on his acceptance to college. However, it did instill in him a fierce interest in human rights and made him a passionate advocate for a negotiated peace to our country's protracted armed conflict. What he learned that summer became part of a larger engagement with the world, intellectually, emotionally, physically and altruistically. It helped him feel a part of something much larger than himself.

This type of engagement and potential for personal growth is what is clearly lacking in the experiences described by Mr. Bruni.

The Jesuits teach that it is noble and gratifying to serve others. It is not noble to take advantage of other's needs or suffering for personal gain. The anecdotes of rich parents buying AIDs clinics in Africa to advance their children's applications to elite universities is frankly repulsive. Victims of disease, armed conflict and poverty are not props to be used by affluent parents.

Thank you Mr. Bruni for exposing such venality and superficiality and for advocating for change in the admission processes at some of the world's leading universities.
They are fooled. That's why it became a trend. Because it worked at one point.  Maybe not now, since all the rich are doing it, but the admissions officers clearly fell for it before.

As the proud father of two Eagle Scouts, I can tell you that service is not a one time thing. It is a practiced lifestyle that eventually becomes part of a person's character. Travel is important as well. The broadest possible view of the world: the good and bad, the happy and sad, the beautiful and ugly need to be seen, heard and experienced first hand.

With that said, I don't think any respectable college or university would be fooled by a one-time trip or one-time service project. Universities look for patterns of service and leadership. They look for inventiveness and a point of view. If you want your child to succeed, I offer you this advice: let them serve from an early age. Include them in complex "adult discussions" and allow them to form a point of view. To the degree possible, let them travel. Keep in mind these things don't have to cost a lot; traveling from Brooklyn to Manhattan can be an inexpensive eye opener and you'd be surprised how many kids have never done it!

Even if they don't get into Harvard, the lessons they'll learn will serve them well for the rest of their lives. Final piece of advice: Scouting is a great way serve, travel, learn skills, make life-long friends and form the foundation for the very pattern universities and employers are looking for.

I hate to point it out, but there is another variable both parental income and kids' SATs correlate strongly (but by no means perfectly) to:  IQ.

I strongly disagree that parental income affects IQ.  I know many parents with limited income whose children have done very well in school.  I also know high-income  parents whose kids have turned out to be less than average in intelligence or income.

The playing field will never be level. Why get overly focused on a few rich people who send their kids abroad, many of whom, have their eyes opened to the state of the world. This time Bruni is focused on creating resentment rather than change.

Admissions officers would be wise to weight the experience of a student who works 20 hours a week in high school at least equally with the kid whose parents pay for these "service" trips.

Left out of this discussion is the fact that the best predictor of SAT scores or likelihood of college degree attainment is family income. America is already a wildly unequal place.

We need fewer practices that further disadvantage the already disadvantaged.

While some service trips abroad do a better job of teaching structural factors than others, the way that the sector and the incentives from college admissions process emphasize "what you can do" takes away focus from structural factors in approaches to international inequality and poverty.

I don't think it's entirely fair to blame the sector or admissions or even the volunteers for this approach -- it's a baked-in narrative in the US that people in the developing world are poor and held back but also resilient, that these are usually people of color, and (more recently) that they are strong in poverty and experience happiness (just like us!) but implicitly do not have agency (financial or, obliquely, otherwise) to solve their own problems. It's a giant American cliche.

Of course these students want to go out and fix these problems! The whole narrative of poverty makes it look easy, like all it takes is some compassion and a passionate kid who cares. The volunteers I worked with were bright, motivated kids who wanted to make a difference. The narrative did not prepare them for reality.

Love this column. You know, we can actually afford to send our daughter on a mission trip. However, we would never do that. Instead, our daughter, on her own, applied for a job with the U.S. Dept. of Agriculture Forest Service  and worked 10 hour days out in the Uintas building fences, checking the fish population, tagging wildlife, etc.   While this may not be a resume building experience, she loved it. And she wants to go back next summer, too. I highly recommend looking into this program for HS students.

"They would not think of being impolite to their neighbor, or their fellow church members, but the do so to someone of a different ethnic group without thinking of it. It shows they are uneducated and know nothing of the world about them."

One summer when my children were small, it became apparent that my child and my neighbor's child needed to understand that rules extended beyond their respective houses. They needed to learn that we parents expected each to act in the other's house in the same manner as we expected them to act in their own house. To a five-year old, this was a revelation, that rules mattered as much when one was abroad as when one was at home. After a couple of backyard over-the-fence chats between us mothers, we explained our expectations to the children, and pretty soon they caught on.

Communities need to explain to their members that consideration for the other needs to extend beyond the community, and that kindness and thoughtfulness matter and are the glue that holds us together, the thing that makes better things possible. Holding to this standard is possible, even amid the current noise, and groups like Smoke Rise Baptist set the example. All that is required, is will.

In my experience. that's selling volunteers a bit short. Many, if not most, of the volunteers I worked with traveled abroad for service and also volunteered at home.

Is it legitimate to criticize people who do international volunteer work for also taking a few days of vacation? Or to seek novelty? Are those bad things?

I hate the idea that people who volunteer must dedicate themselves entirely to their mission, or that somehow being self-effacing and indulging in public self-denial makes you a "better" volunteer. It's ridiculous. Volunteers shouldn't misrepresent vacation time as volunteer time, obviously, but no one tells surgeons that they shouldn't take vacation because there are still people who need surgery.
